sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
The Neotropical social wasp genus
Chartergus
is reviewed and comparative diagnoses, images of type material, and an updated identification key for species are presented. To investigate the phylogenetic relationships within the genus, we used a combined dataset of morphological characters, nest architecture traits, and molecular data. The results revealed the following relationships among the
Chartergus
species: (
C. globiventris
+ (
C. artifex
+
C. metanotalis
)).

sec.title: N/A
Introduction
sec.p:
According to
, the genus shows significant structural diversity in important morphological characters. Currently, there is no phylogenetic hypothesis for
Chartergus
, and the only identification key to the genus is provided by
. Therefore, here we present comparative diagnoses, images of type material, and an updated identification key for the three
Chartergus species.
Additionally, we propose a phylogenetic hypothesis based on molecular and morphological data for the genus and a reassessment of their geographical distribution.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: Taxon sampling and morphological analysis

We examined the type material of
Chartergus
species, including the holotype of
Chartergus globiventris
, two paratypes of
Chartergus metanotalis
(the holotype was lost in the fire at the National Museum of Rio de Janeiro), and the holotype of
Chartergus tuberculatus Cameron, 1906
=
Chartergus artifex
(the holotype of the latter is lost). The type specimen of
C. tuberculatus
is deposited in the Natural History Museum (NHM—London, England ). Additionally, we analyzed specimens from the American Museum of Natural History ( AMNH — New York , USA ) and the Zoology Museum of the Universidade de S„o Paulo ( MZSP —S„o Paulo, Brazil ). We used all of this material to provide comparative diagnoses and update the identification key provided by
. Moreover, we analyzed specimens collected by Malaise traps during a survey in the Northern Region of Brazil for the “Biodiversity of Insects of the Amazon (Rede BIA)” project (for details see
). Those specimens are deposited in the Invertebrate Collection of Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia ( INPA —Manaus, Brazil ).

We constructed a matrix consisting of 22 morphological characters, including 13 characters from adult females, six characters from adult males (including male genitalia), and three characters related to nest architecture (adapted from
) and directly observed on nests deposited in the AMNH collection. We studied morphological characters under a Nikon SMZ645 stereo microscope with an accessory magnifying lens of Nikon G-AL 2x. We obtained images of each species with the aid of a Leica DMC4500 digital camera coupled to a Leica M205A stereomicroscope with a self-assembly system, using the Leica Application Suite v.4.10.0-Montage® software. Nest images come from the AMNH database (Wasp Nest Database, Invertebrate Zoology, American Museum of Natural History—https://emu-prod.amnh.org/imulive/iz/iz.html). We edited the images and assembled the plates using the software ADOBE PHOTOSHOP® CS6 v.6.1.

sec.title: Molecular dataset
Phylogenetic inference
Distribution map
sec.p:
We generated a distribution map for
Chartergus
by compiling data from literature sources and collection records obtained from museums (see Supplementary Material). We georeferenced the locality information from each specimen using the on-line Google Maps Platform. The geographical coordinates were converted to decimal degrees and imported into Quantum-GIS v2.18.18 (Open Source Geospatial Foundation Project, Beaverton, OR, USA ), a free and open source geographic information system to produce a distribution map. Asterisk (*) in the distribution topic means new record of the occurrence for the species.

Diagnosis. Clypeus wider than long, more transverse; clypeus touching the eyes for an extension equal than width of antennal socket; midlength gena equal to or wider than eye; genal margin clearly sinuate a little below the middle of eye, beyond it curved so that the gena becomes very broad again; humeri pronounced; pronotum with an anterior pale transverse band, and with prominence near ventral corner longer and more acute; pronotal fovea absent; scrobal furrow with less regular and usually weaker carinae; metanotum compressed; central tubercle of metanotum stronger; metanotum with a pale band across the top half, rarely partly black here; keel on dorsal half of propodeal angles longer; first metasomal segment wider than long; second metasomal segment as long as wide; usually the largest species in the genus
Chartergus
.

tp:treatment-sec.p: Chartergus chartarius var. globiventris ; Ducke, 1910, Ann. Hist.-Nat. Mus. Natl. Hung. 8: 484, fig. 5.
Epipona globiventris ; Bequaert, 1938, Rev. Entomol., Rio de Janeiro 9: 115 ( Brazil ).

Diagnosis. Clypeus wider than long, less transverse; clypeus touching the eyes for an extension shorter than width of antennal socket; midlength gena equal to wider than eye; genal margin hardly sinuate, sloping up to the mandibles at its lowest point where the gena is also broadest; humeri pronounced; pronotum black, without anterior color band, and with prominence near ventral corner shorter and less acute but often more raised; pronotal fovea absent; scrobal furrow with less regular and usually weaker carinae; metanotum compressed; central tubercle of metanotum very weak, often hardly noticeable; metanotum with a pale band across the top half, rarely partly black here; keel on top half of propodeal angles shorter; first metasomal segment wider than long; second metasomal segment as long as wide. It can be easily differentiated from
C. artifex
and
C. metanotalis
because it has the central tubercle of the metanotum very weak; and is the smallest species in the genus
Chartergus
.

Diagnosis. Clypeus wider than long, more transverse; clypeus touching the eyes for an extension equal than width of antennal socket; midlength gena equal to wider than eye; genal margin usually scarcely sinuate below middle, ventrally bending upwards and running in an almost straight line towards mandibles; humeri pronounced; pronotum with apical whitish yellow band, usually incomplete and stronger in the middle; pronotal keel with a whitish yellow band; without pronotal fovea; scrobal furrow with more or less regular carinae metanotum compressed; central tubercle of metanotum stronger; metanotum nearly always entirely black or with small yellow spots on the sides; first metasomal segment wider than long; second metasomal segment as long as wide.
Chartergus metanotalis
is structurally very close to
C. artifex
but on the average a little smaller, the clypeus and propodeum are usually more coarsely sculptured; and it differs from
C. globiventris
in the much stronger metanotal tubercle.

sec.title: Phylogenetic relationships
sec.p:
Our phylogenetic analyses, based on MP and ML methods ( Fig. 5 ), using a concatenated matrix of morphological and COI mitochondrial data revealed the following relationship among the
Chartergus species
: (
C. globiventris
+ (
C. artifex
+
C. metanotalis
)), with high support (Symmetric Resampling support: 100 for MP; SH-aLRT: 99.4% and UFboot2: 92% for ML). The genus was supported in the MP analysis by two synapomorphies: the presence of the metanotal tubercle (character 2: 1) and the metasomal segment I being wider than long, compressed (character 13: 2), characteristic unique to
Chartergus
among all Epiponini.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
About the phylogeny of
Chartergus
, the species with a very weak central tubercle of the metanotum, often barely noticeable (
C. globiventris
), was recovered at the base of the
Chartergus
clade (character 2: state 1). Conversely, the species with a stronger central tubercle of the metanotum were derived and placed as sister species (
C. artifex
+
C. metanotalis
) (character 2: state 2).
Chartergus globiventris
shows the apex of aedeagus moderate rounded (character 18: state 1) as autapomorphy, while
C. artifex
shows the apex of aedeagus strongly rounded (character 18: state 0), and
C. metanotalis
shows the apex of aedeagus partly truncate (character 18: state 2)

The phylogenetic analysis based on both morphological and molecular data provided valuable insights into the phylogenetic relationships of
Chartergus species.
The recovered phylogeny supported a monophyletic group, with
C . globiventris
positioned as the first lineage of the genus. These findings contribute to our understanding of the morphological variation and phylogenetic relationships of
Chartergus
.

sec.title: Appendix
sec.p: List of Phenotypic Characters in This Work
1—Pronotum, pronotal fovea: present (0), absent (1);
2—Metanotum, metanotal tubercle: absent (0), present, weak (1), present, strong (2);
3—Eye, bristles: absent (0), long (1); short (2);
4—Clypeus, shape: longer than wide (0), wider than long (1);
5—Clypeus, lateral margin, region of contact with eye: convergent (0), parallel (1), divergent (2);
6—Clypeus, contact with eye, extent of the contact: greater than height of antennal socket (0), same height of antennal socket (1); shorter than height of antennal socket (2);
7—Gena, mid height in lateral view, width: narrower than half width of eye (0), wider than half width of eye (1); 8—Humeri, shape: rounded (0), produced (1);
9—Pronotum, pretegular carina: present (0), absent (1);
10—Pronotum, pronotal carina, development: completely (0), only center (1), evanescent (2);
11—Pronotum, lateral region, punctures: absent (0), present (1);
12—Pronotum, lateral region, distance between punctures: sparse (0), contiguous (1);
13—Metasomal segment I, shape: petiolate or longer than wide (0); wider than long, cap-shaped (1); wider than long, compressed (2);
14—Male, gena, width: narrowed (0), wide (1);
15—Male, metapleuron, top, rugosity: not rugose (0), rugose (1);
16—Paramere, apex, width: wider (0), narrower (1);
17—Paramere, parameral spine: stouter, protruding further (0), less stout protruding less far (1);
18—Aedeagus, apex, shape: strongly rounded (0), moderate rounded (1), partly truncate (2);
19—Aedeagus, beneath of center, process: with anterior projection (0), with interior tooth (1), no distinct anterior projection (2);
20—Nest, pedicel: absent (0), present (1);
21—Nest, envelope entrance, locality: ventral (0), multiple (1);
22—Nest, secondary envelopes: absent (0), present (1).
